author: Suncatcher
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
- Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template:

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
 ##
I imported module into user directory

    New-Item "$($profile | split-path)\Modules\AudioDeviceCmdlets" -Type directory -Force
    Copy-Item "C:\Path\to\AudioDeviceCmdlets.dll" "$($profile | split-path)\Modules\AudioDeviceCmdlets\AudioDeviceCmdlets.dll"
    Set-Location "$($profile | Split-Path)\Modules\AudioDeviceCmdlets"
    Get-ChildItem | Unblock-File
    Import-Module AudioDeviceCmdlets
Steps to reproduce
------------------
Now it is listed poperly via 

    Get-Module -ListAvailable -Name AudioDeviceCmdlets`
however I cannot remove it with `Remove-Module`. I tried
```powershell
Remove-Module -Name "AudioDeviceCmdlets"
```
and 
```powershell
"AudioDeviceCmdlets" | Remove-Module -Verbose
```
No luck.

Expected behavior
-----------------

```
VERBOSE: Performing operation "Remove-Module" on Target "filetransfer (Path: 'C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules\filetransfer\filetransfer.psd1')".
VERBOSE: Performing operation "Remove-Module" on Target "Microsoft.BackgroundIntelligentTransfer.Management (Path: 'C:\Windows\assembly\GAC_MSIL\Microsoft.BackgroundIntelligentTransfer.Management\1.0.0.0__31bf3856ad364e35\Microsoft.BackgroundIntelligentTransfe
r.Management.dll')".
VERBOSE: Performing operation "Remove-Module" on Target "psdiagnostics (Path: 'C:\Windows\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules\psdiagnostics\psdiagnostics.psd1')".
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Start-Trace'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Stop-Trace'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Enable-WSManTrace'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Disable-WSManTrace'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Enable-PSWSManCombinedTrace'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Disable-PSWSManCombinedTrace'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Set-LogProperties'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Get-LogProperties'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Enable-PSTrace'.
VERBOSE: Removing imported function 'Disable-PSTrace'.
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```
Remove-Module : No modules were removed. Verify that the specification of modules to remove is correct and those
modules exist in the runspace.
At line:1 char:1
+ Remove-Module -Name "AudioDeviceCmdlets"
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ResourceUnavailable: (:) [Remove-Module], InvalidOperationException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Modules_NoModulesRemoved,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.RemoveModuleCommand
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.16299.251
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.16299.251
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```
Am I doing something wrong?

comments.author: Suncatcher
comments.body:
Also I cannot remove conflicting modules. For example, I have those dup modules (bolded) in the directory:

> Directory: C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules
> ModuleType Version    Name                                ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ----                                ----------------
> Script     1.0.1      Microsoft.PowerShell.Operation.V... {Get-OperationValidation, Invoke-OperationValidation}
> Script     4.2.3      NTFSSecurity                        {Add-NTFSAccess, Clear-NTFSAccess, Disable-NTFSAccessInher...
> **Script     1.1.7.0    PackageManagement                   {Find-Package, Get-Package, Get-PackageProvider, Get-Packa...
> Binary     1.0.0.1    PackageManagement                   {Find-Package, Get-Package, Get-PackageProvider, Get-Packa...**
> Script     3.4.0      Pester                              {Describe, Context, It, Should...}
> **Script     1.6.0      PowerShellGet                       {Install-Module, Find-Module, Save-Module, Update-Module...}
> Script     1.0.0.1    PowerShellGet                       {Install-Module, Find-Module, Save-Module, Update-Module...}**
> Script     1.2        PSReadline                          {Get-PSReadlineKeyHandler, Set-PSReadlineKeyHandler, Remov...

How to remove older versions? Remove-Module runs fine first time, but then they listed via `Get-Module` anyway.

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body:
`Get-Module -ListAvailable -Name AudioDeviceCmdlets` will list modules in the module path. Try `Get-Module -Name AudioDeviceCmdlets` to see if the module is actually loaded in memory. 

WRT to multiple versions of a module loaded in memory, modules are stored in the global module table by full path name. This allows you to have multiple modules with the same name loaded. `Remove-Module 'name'` should remove the first matching module. Running it again should remove the second instance. However, you can remove a specific module version with something like
```
remove-module -FullyQualifiedName @{modulename="nettcpip"; moduleversion="1.0.0.0"}
```

comments.author: Suncatcher
comments.body:
> Try Get-Module -Name AudioDeviceCmdlets to see if the module is actually loaded in memory

No, it is not loaded. If it's not loaded, is it sufficient to remove the file (DLL) from the path directory?

> However, you can remove a specific module version with something like

Tried this command but it failed again


    PS C:\Windows\system32> Get-Module -ListAvailable -Name PackageManagement
    
    
        Directory: C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules
    
    
    ModuleType Version    Name                                ExportedCommands
    ---------- -------    ----                                ----------------
    Script     1.1.7.0    PackageManagement                   {Find-Package, Get-Package, Get-PackageProvider, Get-Packa...
    Binary     1.0.0.1    PackageManagement                   {Find-Package, Get-Package, Get-PackageProvider, Get-Packa...
    
    
    PS C:\Windows\system32> remove-module -FullyQualifiedName @{modulename="PackageManagement"; moduleversion="1.0.0.1"}
    remove-module : No modules were removed. Verify that the specification of modules to remove is correct and those
    modules exist in the runspace.
    At line:1 char:1
    + remove-module -FullyQualifiedName @{modulename="PackageManagement"; m ...
    + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
        + CategoryInfo          : ResourceUnavailable: (:) [Remove-Module], InvalidOperationException
        + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Modules_NoModulesRemoved,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.RemoveModuleCommand
    
    PS C:\Windows\system32>

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body:
> No, it is not loaded.

If it's not loaded then you can't remove it with `Remove-Module` which only removes modules from memory. 

> If it's not loaded, is it sufficient to remove the file (DLL) from the path directory?

Do you mean $ENV:PATH (the executable path) or $ENV:PSModulePath (the module path). Assuming you meant the module path, if you remove the module directory that contains the .dll, then it will no longer be available as a module.

comments.author: Suncatcher
comments.body:
I mean user module path `C:\Users\User\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules`
Okay, so I got it, just to remove the file.
And why does Powershell allow identical modules of different versions with the same commands? How it decides which one to use?

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: You can have multiple versions of a module in in case you need them. For example, you may have scripts that depend on a specific version of a module and can't work with the latest version. Conversely you may have other scripts that only work with the latest version.

title: Imported module is not removed
